[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Treatment of Flu? [/INST]
Overview: Flu antiviral drugs are prescription medicines (pills, liquid, an inhaled powder, or an intravenous solution) that fight against flu in your respiratory tract. Antiviral drugs are not sold over the counter. You can only get them from a pharmacy if you have a prescription from your doctor or health care provider. Antiviral drugs are different from antibiotics, which fight against bacterial infections. Antibiotics do not work against influenza viruses.
Most people with flu have mild illness and do not need medical care or antiviral drugs. If you get sick with flu symptoms, in most cases, you should stay home and avoid contact with other people except to get medical care.
If, however, you have symptoms of flu and are at increased risk for complications, are very sick with flu or worried about your illness, contact your health care provider right away. CDC recommends early treatment as soon as possible for people who have flu or suspected flu who are at higher risk of serious flu complications, such as people with asthma, diabetes, or heart disease.
Most people not at increased risk for flu complications who get sick with flu do not need to be treated with antiviral drugs.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Sinusitis (sinus infection)? [/INST]
Overview: See source for details.

Home care:
• Use saline nasal irrigation or nasal sprays 2-3 times daily
• Apply warm, moist compresses to face for 5-10 minutes several times daily
• Inhale steam from a hot shower or bowl of hot water with a towel over your head
• Stay hydrated with plenty of fluids
• Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air, especially at night
• Elevate your head when sleeping to promote sinus drainage

Medication:
If your sinusitis needs treatment, a pharmacist or GP may prescribe medicines such as:
Rarely, you may need antibiotics. This is not common as sinusitis is usually caused by a virus, not bacteria.
A GP may refer you to see an ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist if you:
An ENT specialist may recommend surgery for some people.

When to seek help:
• Symptoms persist beyond 10 days or worsen after initial improvement
• Severe headache, facial pain, or swelling around the eyes
• High fever (above 38.5°C/101.5°F)
• Visual changes or mental confusion
• Multiple episodes of sinusitis within a year

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Chronic Constipation? [/INST]
Overview: See source for details.

Home care:
   • Increase dietary fiber intake gradually (25-30g daily) through fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
• Drink plenty of fluids (at least 1.5-2 liters of water daily)
• Establish a regular bathroom routine, allowing sufficient time for bowel movements
• Exercise regularly (30 minutes of moderate activity most days)
• Avoid postponing bowel movements when the urge occurs
• Use a footstool while sitting on the toilet to improve positioning

Medication:
• Bulk-forming laxatives (psyllium, methylcellulose) with plenty of water
• Osmotic laxatives (polyethylene glycol, lactulose) for occasional use
• Stool softeners (docusate sodium) for hard stools
• Stimulant laxatives (bisacodyl, senna) for short-term use only
• Prescription medications like lubiprostone, linaclotide, or plecanatide for chronic idiopathic constipation

When to seek help:
• No bowel movement for more than 3-4 days despite home treatments
• Severe abdominal pain or cramping
• Blood in the stool
• Unexplained weight loss
• New onset constipation in adults over 50
• Alternating constipation and diarrhea
• Symptoms that don't improve with self-care measures after 2-3 weeks

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Diarrhoeal disease? [/INST]
Overview: Diarrhoeal disease is the third leading cause of death in children under 5 years old and is responsible for killing around 443 832 children every year. Diarrhoea can last several days and can leave the body without the water and salts that are necessary for survival. In the past, for most people, severe dehydration and fluid loss were the main causes of diarrhoea-associated deaths. Now, other causes such as septic bacterial infections are likely to account for an increasing proportion of all diarrhoea-associated deaths. Children who are malnourished or have impaired immunity, as well as people living with HIV, are most at risk of life-threatening diarrhoea.
Diarrhoea is defined as the passage of 3 or more loose or liquid stools per day (or more frequent passage than is normal for the individual). Frequent passing of formed stools is not diarrhoea, nor is the passing of loose, pasty stools by breastfed babies.
Diarrhoea is usually a symptom of an infection in the intestinal tract, which can be caused by a variety of bacterial, viral and parasitic organisms. Infection is spread through contaminated food or drinking-water, or from person-to-person as a result of poor hygiene.
Interventions to prevent diarrhoea, including safe drinking-water, use of improved sanitation and hand washing with soap, can reduce disease risk. Diarrhoea should be treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS), a solution of clean water, sugar and salt. In addition, a 10–14 day supplemental treatment course of dispersible zinc tablets shortens diarrhoea duration and improves outcomes.
There are 3 clinical types of diarrhoea:

Home care:
• Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration (water, diluted fruit juices, clear broths)
• Use oral rehydration solution (ORS) - mix one packet in clean water according to instructions
• Continue eating regular foods as tolerated, especially easily digestible foods like rice, bananas, toast, and applesauce
• Practice good hand hygiene - wash hands thoroughly with soap and water
• Rest as much as possible to aid recovery
• Clean and disinfect bathroom surfaces regularly to prevent spread

Medication:
• Oral rehydration solution (ORS) is the primary treatment - prepared by dissolving ORS packets in clean water
• Zinc supplements (10-20mg daily for 10-14 days) - reduces severity and duration, especially important for children
• Anti-diarrheal medications generally not recommended, especially for infectious diarrhea or in children
• Antibiotics only when prescribed by healthcare providers for specific bacterial causes
• Probiotics may help restore gut flora, especially after antibiotic treatment

When to seek help:
• Signs of dehydration (extreme thirst, dry mouth, little or no urination, severe weakness, dizziness)
• Blood in stool or black, tarry stools
• Fever above 38.5°C (101.3°F)
• Severe abdominal or rectal pain
• Diarrhea lasting more than 2 days in adults or 24 hours in children
• Signs of severe dehydration in children (sunken eyes, decreased skin elasticity, lethargy)
• Symptoms in infants, elderly, or people with compromised immune systems

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Vitamin D Deficiency? [/INST]
Overview: Vitamin D is essential for bone health and immune function...

Home care:
Sunlight exposure and dietary changes

Medication:
Vitamin D supplements as prescribed

When to seek help: If symptoms of deficiency persist

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Asthma? [/INST]
Overview: See source for details.

Home care:
• Identify and avoid personal triggers (allergens, irritants, exercise, stress)
• Keep rescue inhaler (e.g., albuterol) accessible at all times
• Use peak flow meter daily to monitor lung function if recommended
• Follow your personalized asthma action plan
• Maintain good indoor air quality with air purifiers and regular cleaning
• Practice breathing exercises to improve lung function

Medication:
• Quick-relief medications: Short-acting beta agonists (albuterol) for immediate symptom relief
• Controller medications: Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, budesonide) taken daily
• Combination inhalers: Containing both a corticosteroid and long-acting beta agonist
• Leukotriene modifiers (e.g., montelukast) for some patients
• Biologics for severe, persistent asthma (e.g., omalizumab, mepolizumab)
• Oral corticosteroids for severe flare-ups (short course)

When to seek help:
• Severe shortness of breath that makes it difficult to speak
• No improvement after using rescue inhaler
• Symptoms worsen despite following your asthma action plan
• Peak flow readings fall into your "red zone"
• Bluish tint to lips or fingernails (cyanosis)
• Need to use rescue inhaler more than recommended (typically >2 days per week)
• Nighttime symptoms that disrupt sleep consistently

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Athlete's Foot? [/INST]
Overview: See source for details.

Home care:
• Wash feet thoroughly with soap and water daily, drying completely between toes
• Apply antifungal powder to feet and inside shoes
• Change socks at least once daily, more if feet sweat heavily
• Allow shoes to dry completely between uses (rotate pairs)
• Wear breathable footwear and avoid sharing shoes or towels
• Use shower sandals in public showers, pools, and locker rooms

Medication:
• Over-the-counter antifungal creams, sprays, or powders (terbinafine, clotrimazole, miconazole)
• Apply topical treatment as directed, usually twice daily for 1-2 weeks
• Continue treatment for 1-2 weeks after symptoms resolve to prevent recurrence
• For severe or resistant cases, prescription-strength topical antifungals
• Oral antifungal medications (terbinafine, itraconazole) for extensive infection

When to seek help:
• No improvement after 2 weeks of over-the-counter treatment
• Severe cracking, bleeding, or painful skin
• Signs of bacterial infection (increased warmth, swelling, redness, pus)
• Spreading of the rash to other parts of the body
• Recurrent infections despite appropriate treatment
• If you have diabetes or a compromised immune system

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for Condition? [/INST]
Overview: I'm unable to provide specific treatment recommendations without knowing which medical condition you're asking about. Please specify a particular condition for accurate advice.

Home care:
To receive home care guidance, please ask about a specific medical condition or symptom such as "common cold," "headache," or "sprained ankle."

Medication:
Medication recommendations vary greatly depending on the specific condition. Please specify which condition you're inquiring about for appropriate medication guidance.

When to seek help: 
If you're experiencing concerning symptoms, please consult a healthcare professional immediately. For specific guidance on when to seek help for a particular condition, please ask about that condition directly.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for This page cannot be found? [/INST]
Overview: "This page cannot be found" is not a medical condition but an error message indicating that a webpage you're trying to access doesn't exist or has been moved.

Home care:
• Check the URL to ensure it's typed correctly
• Try accessing the website through its homepage and navigate to the content
• Clear your browser cache and cookies
• Try a different browser or device
• Contact the website administrator if the problem persists

Medication:
No medication is needed for a webpage error. This is a technical issue rather than a medical condition.

When to seek help: 
If you're trying to access important health information and can't find it, please try searching for the topic using a search engine or contact your healthcare provider directly for medical advice.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for 10 Most Prescribed Medicines Around the World and Their Uses? [/INST]
Overview: Prescription medicines are medications aimed to target specific symptoms or illnesses, which require physician care and/or supervision. Doctors use prescriptions to prevent drug misuse, such as over usage, re-selling, or replication, and are often required when purchasing at a pharmacy or dispensary.

Home care:
This appears to be a request for information about common medications rather than a condition requiring treatment. To learn about specific medications, please ask about individual medicines or specific conditions they treat.

Medication:
Common globally prescribed medications include:
• Atorvastatin (Lipitor) - for high cholesterol
• Levothyroxine (Synthroid) - for hypothyroidism
• Metformin - for type 2 diabetes
• Lisinopril - for high blood pressure and heart failure
• Amlodipine - for high blood pressure
• Omeprazole - for acid reflux and ulcers
• Albuterol - for asthma
• Metoprolol - for high blood pressure and angina
• Simvastatin - for high cholesterol
• Gabapentin - for nerve pain and seizures

When to seek help: 
Consult a healthcare provider before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. Seek immediate medical attention for any adverse reactions to medications including severe allergic reactions, difficulty breathing, or unusual symptoms.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for The page can't be found.? [/INST]
Overview: "The page can't be found" is not a medical condition but a technical error message that appears when a webpage cannot be located by your browser.

Home care:
• Double-check the URL for typing errors
• Try reloading the page
• Check your internet connection
• Try searching for the content through a search engine
• Access the website's homepage and navigate to the desired content

Medication:
This is a technical issue with a webpage, not a medical condition requiring medication.

When to seek help: 
If you were looking for medical information when you encountered this error, consider:
• Using a different reliable medical website
• Contacting your healthcare provider directly for the information
• Calling a health helpline in your area for guidance
• Visiting a library for access to medical resources if online access is problematic

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for burn? [/INST]
1. Cool under running water (15–20 °C) for 10–20 min.
2. Gently pat dry and apply 1 % silver sulfadiazine or aloe vera gel.
3. Cover with non‐adhesive sterile dressing and change daily.
4. Ibuprofen 200–400 mg every 6–8 h for pain.
5. Watch for infection (increased redness, swelling, pus).

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for cold flu? [/INST]
1. Rest and limit activity for 2–3 days.
2. Drink ≥2 L fluids daily (water, broth, tea).
3. Paracetamol 500 mg or ibuprofen 200–400 mg every 6 h for fever/aches.
4. Saline nasal spray 3 times/day; lozenges or cough syrup PRN.
5. If ≤48 h since symptom onset, consider antiviral per guidelines.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for diarrhoea vomiting? [/INST]
1. Sip 5–10 mL ORS every 5 min until tolerating.
2. After 4 h symptom‐free, introduce BRAT diet.
3. Loperamide 2 mg after first stool, then 1 mg PRN (max 8 mg/24 h).
4. Ondansetron 4 mg once if severe vomiting (prescription).
5. Seek care if dehydration, blood in stool, or >10 episodes/day.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for earache? [/INST]
1. Warm compress over ear for 10 min every 2 h.
2. Ibuprofen 200–400 mg every 6 h for pain and fever.
3. If otitis externa, apply antibiotic‐steroid ear drops per Rx.
4. Keep ear dry; avoid cotton swabs.
5. Refer if pain persists >48 h or hearing loss worsens.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for fever child? [/INST]
1. Paracetamol 15 mg/kg every 6 h (max 4 doses/24 h).
2. Tepid sponge baths if temp >39 °C.
3. Offer ≥100 mL/kg/day of fluids (water, ORS).
4. Light clothing and cool room (20–22 °C).
5. Seek ER if <3 months old, febrile seizure, or <50 mL urine/8 h.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for worms? [/INST]\nMebendazole 100 mg single dose; repeat in 2 weeks.
[INST] What is the recommended treatment for nosebleed? [/INST]\nLean forward, pinch nostrils 10 min, ice pack on nose, seek ENT if >20 min.
[INST] What is the recommended treatment for sore throat? [/INST]\nGargle saltwater ½ tsp/240 mL q4h, acetaminophen 500 mg q6h, humidifier at night.
[INST] What is the recommended treatment for sprain? [/INST]\nRICE: rest, ice 20 min q2h, compression wrap, elevate above heart.
[INST] What is the recommended treatment for sunburn? [/INST]\nCool baths, aloe vera gel, ibuprofen 200–400 mg q6h, avoid sun for 48 h.

[INST] My head feels heavy and achy around my sinuses, especially when I bend forward—any relief tips? [/INST]
• Perform a saline nasal rinse or steam inhalation to clear congestion
• Apply a warm compress over your cheeks and the bridge of your nose
• Take an OTC decongestant (e.g., pseudoephedrine) if you have no contraindications
• Stay hydrated and rest in a slightly elevated position

If pain is severe, lasts more than 7 days, or you develop a high fever, see a doctor.

[INST] I get a sharp, burning pain behind my left eye early every morning—could this be a cluster headache? What helps? [/INST]
• Sit or lie in a dark, quiet room at episode onset
• Apply a cold pack to your eye region for 5–10 minutes
• Practice deep, slow breathing to calm your nervous system
• Avoid alcohol and high‐altitude changes, which can trigger attacks

If you experience more than one attack per day, consider seeing a neurologist for prescription treatment.

[INST] I often feel a pulsating pain around my temples that lasts 30–45 minutes—suggestions for quick relief? [/INST]
• Gently massage your temples and the back of your neck
• Use a cold or warm towel on your forehead to see which soothes you more
• Take ibuprofen (200–400 mg) or paracetamol (500 mg) as directed
• Practice progressive muscle relaxation for 5–10 minutes

Should these episodes become more frequent, consult a healthcare provider for preventive options.

[INST] There’s a constant pressure in my forehead and around my eyes with slight nasal stuffiness—what can I do at home? [/INST]
• Try a neti pot or saline spray twice daily to reduce mucosal swelling
• Use a steam inhalation (hot shower or bowl of hot water) to loosen mucus
• Take an expectorant like guaifenesin if mucus is thick
• Elevate your head when sleeping to help drainage

See an ENT specialist if symptoms persist beyond 10 days or worsen.

[INST] I feel a burning sensation in my upper stomach after meals and sometimes a sour taste—how can I ease this? [/INST]
• Take an OTC antacid (e.g., calcium carbonate) 1–2 hours after eating
• Sip ginger or chamomile tea to soothe your stomach lining
• Eat smaller, more frequent meals and avoid spicy/fatty foods
• Stay upright for 2–3 hours after eating to prevent reflux

If heartburn occurs more than twice a week, talk to your doctor about prescription options.

[INST] What is the recommended treatment for the common cold? [/INST]
• Rest and stay hydrated
• Use saline nasal spray or drops
• Take over-the-counter analgesics (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen)
• Use a humidifier or inhale steam
• Gargle warm salt water for sore throat

If symptoms worsen or last more than 10 days, consult a physician.

[INST] How should influenza (flu) be treated at home? [/INST]
• Rest in bed and drink plenty of fluids
• Use acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever and aches
• Consider antiviral medications (oseltamivir) within 48 hours of onset
• Use cough suppressants and lozenges for throat comfort

Seek medical attention for difficulty breathing, high fever, or dehydration.

[INST] What are the treatment options for sinusitis? [/INST]
• Apply warm compresses over sinuses
• Perform nasal saline irrigation twice daily
• Use decongestants (pseudoephedrine) for short-term relief
• Take analgesics for pain (acetaminophen, ibuprofen)
• For bacterial cases, a physician may prescribe antibiotics

See a doctor if symptoms persist beyond 10 days or worsen.

[INST] How is strep throat treated? [/INST]
• Confirm diagnosis with a rapid strep test or throat culture
• Prescribe penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days
• Use acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain and fever
• Gargle warm salt water to soothe the throat
• Stay hydrated and rest the voice

Finish the full antibiotic course even if you feel better.

[INST] What can I do to relieve a persistent cough? [/INST]
• Drink warm fluids (tea, honey water)
• Use over-the-counter cough suppressants (dextromethorphan)
• Use expectorants (guaifenesin) to loosen mucus
• Inhale steam or use a humidifier

If cough lasts more than three weeks or is productive of blood, see a doctor.

[INST] How should acute bronchitis be managed? [/INST]
• Rest and increase fluid intake
• Use humidified air or steam inhalation
• Take analgesics for fever and discomfort
• Avoid smoking and pulmonary irritants
• Antibiotics are usually not needed unless bacterial infection is confirmed

Seek medical attention if breathing difficulty arises.

[INST] What treatments help tension headaches? [/INST]
• Apply a warm or cold compress to the forehead or neck
• Perform gentle neck and shoulder stretches
• Take over-the-counter pain relief (ibuprofen, acetaminophen)
• Practice relaxation techniques and manage stress

If headaches become chronic, consult a healthcare provider for preventive therapy.

[INST] How do you treat acute back pain? [/INST]
• Rest for the first 24–48 hours, then resume gentle movement
• Apply ice for inflammation, then heat after 48 hours
• Take NSAIDs (ibuprofen) or acetaminophen
• Perform light stretching and strengthen core muscles

See a clinician if pain persists beyond two weeks or worsens.

[INST] What is the treatment protocol for a sprained ankle? [/INST]
• RICE: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation
• Apply ice packs for 15–20 minutes every 2–3 hours
• Use a compression bandage and elevate above heart level
• After 48 hours, perform gentle range-of-motion exercises

Seek medical evaluation for severe swelling or inability to bear weight.

[INST] How can indigestion be relieved at home? [/INST]
• Eat smaller, more frequent meals
• Avoid spicy, fatty, or acidic foods
• Take antacids (calcium carbonate) as needed
• Sip ginger or peppermint tea

If indigestion is persistent or associated with weight loss, get evaluated.

[INST] What home remedies help heartburn and GERD? [/INST]
• Avoid trigger foods (citrus, caffeine, chocolate)
• Eat smaller meals and don’t lie down immediately after eating
• Elevate the head of the bed by 6–8 inches
• Take H2 blockers (ranitidine) or proton-pump inhibitors (omeprazole)

See a doctor if heartburn occurs more than twice a week.

[INST] How is gastritis treated? [/INST]
• Avoid alcohol, NSAIDs, and irritant foods
• Eat small, bland meals throughout the day
• Take antacids or H2 blockers (famotidine)
• For H. pylori infection, use combination antibiotics and a PPI

Consult your physician for persistent abdominal pain or bleeding.

[INST] How do you manage acute diarrhea? [/INST]
• Drink plenty of clear fluids (ORS, broth)
• Follow the BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast)
• Avoid dairy, caffeine, and high-fiber foods
• Use loperamide (Imodium) if no fever or bloody stools

Seek medical care for dehydration or bloody diarrhea.

[INST] What treatments are recommended for constipation? [/INST]
• Increase dietary fiber (fruits, vegetables, whole grains)
• Drink 1.5–2 L of water daily
• Engage in regular physical activity
• Use bulk-forming laxatives (psyllium) or stool softeners

Discuss chronic constipation with your healthcare provider.

[INST] How can I recover from food poisoning? [/INST]
• Rest and sip clear fluids frequently
• Avoid solid foods until vomiting subsides
• Gradually reintroduce bland foods (BRAT diet)
• Consider ORS to maintain electrolyte balance

Seek urgent care for high fever, bloody stools, or severe dehydration.

[INST] What is the standard treatment for acne? [/INST]
• Cleanse skin gently twice daily
• Apply topical benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid
• Use topical retinoids for comedonal acne
• For moderate cases, dermatologists may prescribe antibiotics

Follow-up if acne is severe or scarring occurs.

[INST] How is atopic eczema managed? [/INST]
• Keep skin moisturized with emollients
• Use topical corticosteroids for flare-ups
• Avoid known irritants and allergens
• Bathe in lukewarm water and pat skin dry

See a dermatologist for severe or widespread eczema.

[INST] What treatments help athlete’s foot? [/INST]
• Keep feet clean and dry
• Apply topical antifungals (terbinafine) twice daily
• Wear breathable, moisture-wicking socks
• Change shoes and socks daily

Seek prescription therapy if no improvement after 2–3 weeks.

[INST] How can dandruff be treated? [/INST]
• Use anti-dandruff shampoo with zinc pyrithione or ketoconazole
• Shampoo 2–3 times weekly, leave on for 5 minutes
• Rinse thoroughly and avoid harsh hair products

If dandruff persists, consult a dermatologist.

[INST] What are the home-care steps for sunburn? [/INST]
• Cool the skin with damp compresses
• Apply aloe vera gel or moisturizing lotion
• Take NSAIDs for pain and inflammation
• Stay hydrated and avoid further sun exposure

Seek medical care for blistering over large areas or systemic symptoms.

[INST] How do you treat cold sores? [/INST]
• Apply topical antiviral cream (docosanol) at first tingle
• Take oral antivirals (acyclovir) for frequent outbreaks
• Keep the area clean and avoid touching
• Use lip balm with sunscreen to prevent recurrence

See your doctor if lesions are severe or immunocompromised.

[INST] What treatments are used for contact dermatitis? [/INST]
• Identify and avoid the irritant or allergen
• Apply topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation
• Use emollients to repair the skin barrier
• Take oral antihistamines for itching relief

If rash is widespread or infected, seek medical advice.

[INST] How is conjunctivitis (pink eye) treated? [/INST]
• For viral: apply cool compresses and artificial tears
• For bacterial: use prescribed antibiotic eye drops/ointment
• Avoid contact lenses until cleared
• Maintain good hygiene to prevent spread

Consult an ophthalmologist for vision changes or severe pain.

[INST] What is recommended for otitis media (ear infection)? [/INST]
• Apply warm compress to the affected ear
• Use OTC pain relievers (ibuprofen, acetaminophen)
• For bacterial cases, a doctor may prescribe antibiotics
• Keep the ear dry during bathing

Seek care if fever persists or hearing loss develops.

[INST] How do you treat a urinary tract infection (UTI)? [/INST]
• Drink plenty of water and cranberry juice
• Take prescribed antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)
• Use analgesics (phenazopyridine) for urinary pain
• Urinate frequently to help clear bacteria

Follow up if symptoms persist after antibiotic course.

[INST] What treatments help a vaginal yeast infection? [/INST]
• Use OTC antifungal creams or suppositories (miconazole)
• Wear breathable cotton underwear
• Avoid douching and scented hygiene products
• Take probiotics to restore normal flora

See a clinician if symptoms recur or worsen.

[INST] How should hemorrhoids be managed at home? [/INST]
• Apply witch hazel pads or sitz baths for soothing relief
• Use topical hydrocortisone creams
• Increase dietary fiber and fluid intake
• Avoid straining during bowel movements

If bleeding or pain persists, consult a healthcare provider.

[INST] What can be done for motion sickness relief? [/INST]
• Take OTC antihistamines (meclizine) before travel
• Sit where motion is minimal (front seat, over the wing)
• Focus on the horizon and avoid reading
• Ginger supplements or tea may reduce nausea

If severe, consult a doctor for prescription patches.

[INST] How do you provide first aid for minor burns? [/INST]
• Cool the burn under running water for 10–20 minutes
• Cover with a non-adhesive, sterile dressing
• Take ibuprofen or acetaminophen for pain
• Do not apply ice or butter to the burn

Seek medical attention for burns covering large areas or blistering.

[INST] What is the treatment for dehydration? [/INST]
• Drink oral rehydration solutions (ORS)
• Sip clear fluids frequently (water, broth)
• Avoid caffeine and alcohol

Seek urgent care for severe dehydration signs: dizziness, rapid heartbeat.

[INST] How is heat exhaustion treated? [/INST]
• Move to a cool, shaded area immediately
• Lie down and elevate the legs
• Sip cool water or sports drinks slowly
• Apply cool, wet cloths to the body

Seek emergency care if symptoms worsen or consciousness is impaired.

[INST] What home remedies help mouth ulcers? [/INST]
• Rinse with saltwater or baking soda solution
• Apply topical gels containing benzocaine
• Avoid spicy, acidic foods
• Maintain good oral hygiene

See a dentist if ulcers persist beyond two weeks.

[INST] How should I choose between paracetamol and ibuprofen? [/INST]
• Paracetamol for mild pain and fever—gentler on the stomach
• Ibuprofen for inflammation and menstrual cramps
• Do not exceed recommended daily doses

Consult your doctor if you have liver, kidney, or GI issues.

[INST] What is the antibiotic guidance for otitis media? [/INST]
• Watchful waiting for 48–72 hours in mild cases
• Prescribe amoxicillin for bacterial infections in children
• Use amoxicillin-clavulanate if no response or recent antibiotic use

Follow up to ensure resolution and prevent complications.

[INST] How are antihistamines used to treat allergies? [/INST]
• Take oral antihistamines (cetirizine, loratadine) daily during allergy season
• Use nasal antihistamine sprays (azelastine) for nasal symptoms
• Avoid known allergens and keep windows closed

Consult an allergist for immunotherapy if symptoms persist.

[INST] What should I know about using decongestants? [/INST]
• Use oral decongestants (pseudoephedrine) for short-term relief
• Apply topical nasal sprays (oxymetazoline) for no more than 3 days
• Avoid in patients with hypertension or glaucoma

If congestion lasts more than one week, check for sinusitis.

[INST] How are antidiarrheal medications used? [/INST]
• Use loperamide for acute, non-bloody diarrhea
• Take bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol) for mild cases
• Continue fluids and BRAT diet

Avoid antidiarrheals with fever or bloody stools; seek medical care.

[INST] What are the options for treating constipation? [/INST]
• Bulk-forming agents (psyllium) with plenty of water
• Osmotic laxatives (polyethylene glycol) for gentle relief
• Stool softeners (docusate) if straining

Contact your doctor for chronic or painful constipation.

[INST] How do antacids compare to proton-pump inhibitors? [/INST]
• Antacids (calcium carbonate) provide rapid, short-term relief
• PPIs (omeprazole) reduce acid production for longer control
• Use antacids as needed and PPIs for frequent heartburn

Discuss long-term PPI use with your physician.

[INST] What is the role of oral rehydration salts (ORS)? [/INST]
• ORS replaces fluids and electrolytes lost in diarrhea
• Mix packet with clean water per instructions
• Sip frequently, especially in children and elderly

Use alongside dietary measures; seek care for severe dehydration.

[INST] When should NSAIDs be used for pain relief? [/INST]
• Use ibuprofen or naproxen for inflammatory pain (arthritis, muscle strains)
• Follow dosing instructions; take with food to protect stomach
• Avoid long-term use without medical supervision

Consult a clinician for chronic pain management.
